Investigating the CrOx/Al2O3 dehydrogenation catalyst model: I. identification and stability evaluation of the Cr species on the fresh and equilibrated catalysts Vladimir Z. Fridman ⁎ Rong Xing Michael Severance Clariant Corporation, Louisville, KY, 40209, United States Clariant Corporation Louisville KY 40209 United States ⁎ Corresponding author at: 600 Hill Street, Louisville, KY 40210, United States. Graphical abstract In this study a series of the fresh and equilibrated CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with the Cr loading from 0.58wt% to 13.2wt% were in detail studied using combined techniques, including Raman spectroscopy, TEM, XPS, O2 chemisorption, TPR, XRD and chemical analysis, to identify surface chromium species and to evaluate their stability under the cyclic dehydrogenation-regeneration (redox) conditions. The study showed that the stable chromium species present in the equilibrated CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst can be achieved through complete surface restructuring of initial chromium species in the fresh one under the redox conditions. This study also showed that the fresh CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst contained not only previously known chromium species of ‘isolated’ mono/poly aluminum chromate(s), amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 clusters with different sizes, but also chromium-chromate (Cr6+) species on the surface of Cr2O3 clusters and aluminum-chromium-chromate (Cr6+) species coupled with Cr2O3 clusters. The ‘isolated’ aluminum chromate(s) and small Cr2O3 clusters on the catalyst surface were not stable under the cyclic redox conditions and disappeared after the break-in-period of the catalyst operation. The paper presents the mechanism of the surface restructuring of chromium species under the redox conditions and the revised model for the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst with the consideration of the change of surface chromium species caused by the cyclic redox aging. The model can be applied to the commercial CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts. Keywords CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst Surface chromium species Stability Paraffin dehydrogenation Model 1 Introduction One of the largest applications of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts in the chemical industry is the cyclic paraffin dehydrogenation technology, which is currently used in the Yarsyntez-Snamprogetti fluid bed dehydrogenation process and the Houdry dehydrogenation process known as CATOFIN® and CATADIENE® processes [1–3]. Both processes employ the dehydrogenation-regeneration (redox) mode of operation in which a dehydrogenation reaction step is followed by a catalyst regeneration step. The commercial fixed-bed CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts typically experience ∼60,000–80,000 dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles depending on the severity and the cycle time of the operation. The CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst has been the subject of significant research in the field of paraffin dehydration due to its low cost, high activity, and good stability. There is a large amount of literatures that have discussed different aspects of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst including the catalyst preparation, the nature of active sites, and the catalyst models [4–36]. There have been several studies showing that the characteristic of the Cr species is strongly dependent on the nature of the support, the Cr loading, and the method of preparation [4–11,33–36]. So far, several Cr species have been widely reported on the fresh CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst surface after the catalyst was prepared and calcined in the oxidative atmosphere, such as (1) the Cr6+ species, including the water soluble Cr6+ and the grafted Cr6+ which is insoluble in water and chemically bonded with alumina in the form of monomer, dimer, and polymer with different nuclearity, (2) the Cr3+ species including non-redox Cr3+ sites and redox Cr3+ sites that can be oxidized into Cr5+ and Cr6+ during the regeneration, (3) amorphous Cr2O3 clusters with different sizes, and 4) crystalline α-Cr2O3 clusters with different sizes. It is worth noting that the non-redox Cr3+ species were also assigned as isolated Cr3+ ions in strong interaction with alumina or as clustered amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3-like species on the alumina surface. The isolated Cr3+ species have been reported by a few research groups [22,37–40], in which Slinkin and coworks [38] observed the formation of δ-phase or dispersed Cr induced by the isolated Cr3+ species locating far and not interacting with each other based on the electron spin resonance (ESR) studies. It was found that the increase of the Cr loading in the catalyst caused the gradual disappearance of δ-phase which was converted into magneto-concentrated β-phase of Cr2O3 clusters [34]. This suggests that the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst with the high Cr loading probably had few or very small amount of isolated Cr3+ species. In addition, the isolated Cr5+ species were also detected to be present on the CrxO/Al2O3 catalyst surface by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) after the preparation and regeneration [28,34,41]. However, the existence of the Cr5+ species has been questioned by Khaddar-Zine who claimed that the appearance of Cr5+ signal in the EPR spectra was caused by the formation of the oligomer-like structures, i.e., Cr6+ −O2− −Cr3+ −O2−Cr6+, which can provide electron transfer via the reversible reaction of (Cr6+ −O2− −Cr3+ −O2−Cr6+)⇆(Cr5+ −O2− −Cr5+ −O2−Cr5+) [42] or acts as a three-chromium-center with mixed valence and an average oxidation degree of 5 as reported by Spitz [41]. The Cr species after the reduction part of the cycle were mostly in the form of Cr3+, and likely in Cr2+ oxidation states. The model CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with a low Cr loading usually contain one or two types of Cr species on their surface. However, the commercial CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst typically requires 11–16wt% of Cr, at which level a heterogeneous distribution of Cr species is unavoidable in the catalyst [4–11]. Various Cr species on the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst surface complicate the identification of the catalyst active sites for paraffin dehydrogenation reactions. Although the majority of the Cr species formed on the catalyst surface is known, there are still many discussions regarding whether those species are present on the commercial catalyst surface, what the nature of the dehydrogenation active sites is, and how much contribution of each species to the catalyst activity. During the last 60 years, many research groups viewed their opinions regarding the active sites of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst for the dehydrogenation reactions [4–8,12–16,20–22,25,27,28]. One of the earlier studies showed that the Cr6+ species are the active sites for the dehydrogenation reactions [4,5]. Since the 1960s, several groups have found that the reduction of the CrOx/Al2O3 and/or CrOx/SiO2 catalysts led to the formation of Cr2+ species which were considered as the active sites for the dehydrogenation reactions based on some indirect evidence [12–16] like ESR by Ashmavy [12]. Although X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) later showed that there was no Cr2+ species observed on the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst surface after the reduction [17–19], there is still a theoretical possibility of their presence. Currently, a majority of the authors consider the Cr3+ ions as the active centers in the CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts for paraffin dehydrogenation reactions [6–8,14,20,22,25,27,28], where the Cr3+ ions comprise both the redox and the non-redox Cr3+ sites. However, there are still unanswered questions regarding the activity and stability of the Cr species on the catalyst surface. Another reason to investigate the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst was to improve the existing catalyst models, most of which were developed for the fresh CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts [6–8,12,14,20,22,25,27,28]. It is known that the fresh CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst significantly changes its initial properties after an initial period of several days of operation in the cyclic redox mode, called ‘break-in period’ in the industry. After the break-in period, the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst can be operated for thousands of cycles without a significant loss of the activity, showing that the surface Cr species have good stability. In contrast to the fresh catalyst, the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst after the break-in period was called the equilibrated catalyst in this paper. So far there has been only a few reports that have taken the change of initial properties the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst into account. For example, Weckhuysen’s group recently reported an on-line approach to studying the commercial-like CrOx catalyst in an industrial propane dehydrogenation reactor using combined operando Raman spectroscopy and UV–vis spectroscopy [43–46]. Although their study provided interesting information on the redox behavior during a cycling operation, the coke type and amount formed on the industrial-like CrOx/alumina catalysts during the aging, there is little information on the identification and stability evaluation of surface Cr species before and after the aging. The primary objectives of this work were to identify the surface Cr species, to determine the change of Cr species during the redox operation, and to evaluate the stability of different Cr species present on the fresh and equilibrated catalysts. Another objective is to propose a new CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst model with the consideration of the change of surface chromium species caused by the cyclic redox aging, which can be applied to the commercial catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Since the characteristic of the Cr species on the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst surface strongly depends on the Cr loading [4–11], a series of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with different Cr loadings, i.e., 0.58, 1.34, 4.62, 7.21, 9.93, 13.23wt%, have been prepared by the impregnation of alumina with the CrO3 aqueous solution in the presence of small amount of alkali metal ions as described before [47]. For direct comparison, a high crystalline purity (>99%) α-Cr2O3 sample was made by the calcination of CrO3 powder at 760°C in air for 6h and was designated as the Cr-100. Table 1 summarizes the samples studied in this work. After the impregnation, the catalysts were first dried in air overnight, followed by the calcination at 760°C for 4h using a 15%O2/N2 gas stream. The temperature of 760°C was selected to provide a complete conversion of the CrO3 into α-Cr2O3 and to minimize the formation of Cr6+ species. Thus, it should be noted that until otherwise specified, all physical properties reported in this paper refer to fully dehydrated catalysts. 2.2 Dehydrogenation activity test The dehydrogenation activity tests were conducted in a testing unit that simulates the commercial cyclic dehydrogenation-regeneration process and is operated in successive cycles of reduction, dehydrogenation, and regeneration. The detailed testing procedure was described in the previous paper [48]. To obtain the equilibrated catalyst, the fresh catalyst was thermally treated in the redox mode at 600°C for 300 cycles. This method of catalyst treatment was validated by comparing the properties of the industrial-like Al-Cr-13.2% catalyst with those having similar composition but taken from the commercial reactor after the breaking-in-period operation. The activity of the fresh and equilibrated catalysts was tested by the dehydrogenation of isobutane at a pressure of 0.5bar (absolute), a reaction contact time of 0.83s, and in the temperature range of 480–540°C. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations In this work, the fresh and equilibrated catalysts were extensively characterized using the following analytical techniques: N2 adsorption, O2 chemisorption, Raman spectroscopy, STEM/EDX, XPS, XRD, H2-TPR, and chemical analysis for the concentration of the total Cr, Cr2+, and Cr6+ ions. 2.3.1 Analysis of Cr2+ species An Autochem (II) apparatus (Micromeritics) equipped with a Mass-spectrometer was applied to determine the “potential” amount of Cr2+ formable in the catalyst. The method was previously reported based on the Reaction (1) [12,16]. (1) 2CrO +H2O→Cr2O3 +H2 Before the analysis, the catalyst was first reduced at 600°C in ultrahigh purity and dry hydrogen (the feed gas was pretreated with molecular sieve to remove residual water before introduced to the reactor). Then, the reduced catalyst was purged for ∼1h with ultrahigh purity and dry He (the feed was also pretreated with molecular sieve to remove residual water). Finally, the resulting catalyst was oxidized by steam pulses at 600°C. Once water was injected on the surface of the reduced catalyst, the outlet gas was analyzed by the mass-spectrometer to determine the H2 amount which was used to calculate the Cr2+ concentration in the catalyst. 2.3.2 Analysis of Cr3+and Cr6+ species The fresh and equilibrated catalysts were analyzed for the total Cr and Cr6+ concentration by a titration method [49]. To determine the total Cr concentration, the sample was digested by a mixture of sulfuric and phosphoric acid. The catalysts were also analyzed for the amounts of grafted and free Cr6+ in the catalyst. The grafted Cr6+ amount was determined by measuring the residual amount of Cr6+ after washing catalyst by cold water [20]. The free Cr6+ amount was calculated as a difference between the total amount of Cr6+ and the amount of the grafted Cr6+. The difference between the total Cr amount and the sum of Cr2+ and Cr6+ amount in the catalyst was used to calculate the amount of Cr3+. 2.3.3 H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2_TPR) measurement The TPR experiments were carried out on an Autochem (II) apparatus (Micromeritics) equipped with a TCD detector. Typically, 0.1g catalyst was first loaded into a U-type quartz tube. The sample was first dried in Argon at 150°C at a ramping rate of 8°C/min for 1h, followed by cooling down the sample to room temperature. Then a gas stream containing 5% H2/Ar was flown through the sample. The temperature was increased from 25°C up to 1000°C at a ramping rate of 8°C/min, during which the H2 consumption was recorded. 2.3.4 O2 chemisorption measurement The O2 chemisorption experiments were conducted by the pulse technique using Autochem (II) apparatus (Micromeritics) at −78°C. The obtained data were applied to calculate the surface area of chromium oxide and average particle size of chromium oxide particles using the previous approach [50]. 2.3.5 N2 adsorption measurement BET surface area of the catalysts were measured by nitrogen adsorption at 77K with an automatic adsorption instrument (Micromeritics). Surface areas were determined from adsorption values at five relative pressure values (P/P0) ranging from 0.05 to 0.2 using the BET method. 2.3.6 Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The phase composition of the samples was studied by XRD. Diffractograms were measured by a Siemens D5000 X-ray diffractometer, and the phases were identified with a database of Siemens Diffrac AT program (@ 1993). The diffractometer was calibrated to determine the concentration of α-Cr2O3 phase and solid solution of α-Cr2O3 in α-Al2O3 if present. The concentration of α-Cr2O3 phase was calculated based on the intensities of the bands at the d space of 1.67Å and 2.18Å, and the concentration of solid solution α-(Cr, Al) phase if present was calculated based on the intensities of the bands at the d space of 1.61Å, 1.74Å, 2.1Å, and 2.56Å. The amount of amorphous Cr2O3 in each sample was determined by the difference between the total Cr3+ amount and the α-Cr2O3 concentration determined by XRD. 2.3.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis The XPS measurements were performed using a VG Thermo MultiLab 3000 surface analysis system inside a multi chamber ultra-high vacuum (UHV) surface science facility (VG Scientific/RHK Technology) equipped with a 150mm radius CLAM 4 hemispherical analyzer. The base chamber pressure was ∼10−9 Torr. All the measurements were performed with use of Mg Ka X-rays with characteristic energy of 1253.6eV. High-resolution Al2s, O1s and Cr2p3/2 spectra were collected and analyzed each sample. Elemental quantification was performed using XPS MultiQuant software. Atomic Sensitivity Factors (ASF) were used to account for the sensitivity difference. 2.3.8 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis Scanning transmission electron microscopy/energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (STEM/EDX) was performed using a TECNAI F20 TEM operated at 200kV with a nanoprobe of the beam diameter of ∼1nm. For each sample, a number of EDX maps were collected to estimate the Cr particle size. Typically, each sample was prepared by scrapping catalyst surface using a clean razor blade and crashing the scrapped material between two glass plates. The resulting fine powder was then dispersed on a Lacey carbon grid for TEM analysis. 2.3.9 UV-Raman spectroscopy analysis Raman scans were conducted in a Renishaw InVia Microscope equipped with a 325nm He-Cd laser with 0.2mW power. Raman spectra were recorded at ambient conditions using the fully dehydrated samples, and the range of the wavenumber was varied between 450cm−1 and 2000cm−1. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst color and Cr6+ concentration in the fresh and equilibrated catalysts Chemical analysis of the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst shows that it contained 0.58% of Cr6+ that was equal to the total Cr loading in this catalyst, suggesting that 100% of Cr in the Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst was present in the form of Cr6+ species (Table 2 , columns 1 and 7). Increasing the Cr loading up to 1.34% resulted in the increase of the total Cr6+ concentration to 0.77% (Fig. 1 A, Table 2, column 1). This indicates that the portion of Cr6+ species relative to the total Cr in the catalyst was reduced from 100% in the Al-Cr-0.58 to ∼57.5% in the Al-Cr-1.3. The remaining 42.5% Cr in the fresh Al-Cr-1.3 catalyst was identified as the Cr3+ species in the form of amorphous Cr2O3 (Fig. 1, Table 2, columns 1, 7 and 9). In addition, it was found that the increase of Cr3+ portion was accompanied with the catalyst color changing from yellowish in both the Al-Cr-0.58 and the Al-Cr-1.34 catalysts, to greenish in the Al-Cr-7.2 catalyst, and to bright green in the higher Cr loading catalysts (>7.2% Cr). The change of catalyst color with the increase of Cr3+ portion provided additional evidence that the majority of Cr species was in the form of Cr3+ species for the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst at higher Cr loadings (>7.2%). Unlike the results reported by Cavani [20], the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 and Al-Cr-1.34 catalysts had very small amount of grafted Cr6+ species (Table 2, column 5), while the fresh catalysts with the Cr loading of 4.62% or higher contained ∼30% of the grafted Cr6+ species. For the equilibrated catalysts, the Cr6+ concentration was drastically reduced. For example, the equilibrated Al-Cr-0.58 and Al-Cr-1.34 catalysts lost ∼92% and ∼86% of the initial Cr6+ species, respectively, as compared to their fresh counterparts (Fig. 1A, Table 2, column 2). This indicates that the Cr6+ species formed on the fresh catalyst surfaces were not stable. The change of the catalyst color from yellowish to light green in the two samples also suggests the decrease of the Cr6+ concentration was possibly caused by the conversion of the redox Cr6+ into Cr3+ species. Further increase of the Cr loading from 0.58 to 4.62% caused the growth of the Cr6+ species in both fresh and equilibrated catalysts (Fig. 1A, Table 2, columns 1 and 2). The increase of the Cr loading from 7.21 to 13.23% led to only marginal growth of the Cr6+, indicating that the surface Cr6+ species have achieved the saturation level (Fig. 1A, Table 2, columns 1 and 2). However, the equilibrated catalyst showed faster increase of the Cr6+ concentration than the fresh one. For example, the measured Cr6+ concentration in the equilibrated catalyst increased from 0.05 to 0.55% by 10 times as the Cr loading increased from 0.58 to 13.2%, as compared to the increase of Cr6+ concentration by 84% for the fresh catalyst. As a result, a higher portion of Cr6+ species was present on the surface of equilibrated catalysts with a higher Cr loading. For example, the Cr6+ concentration in the equilibrated Al-Cr-13.2% was ∼51% of the initial Cr6+ concentration in the fresh catalyst. This observation suggests that the Cr6+ species in the Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst had improved stability as compared to other catalysts. 3.2 Analysis of Cr2+ species All fresh and equilibrated catalysts were tested to determine the concentration of Cr2+ species based on the reaction (1). However, there was no H2 detected during the contact of the reduced catalyst with steam. It was thus postulated that Cr2+ species were not formed on the surfaces of the tested catalysts. 3.3 XRD analysis The XRD of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with the Cr loading of 0.58% and 1.34% only shows peaks attributed to the initial alumina (not shown for brevity). The XRD of the Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst shows the presence of trace amount of α-Cr2O3 and the initial alumina. Since the peak of α-Cr2O3 was small, its concentration in the catalyst was estimated in this work. The XRD of the catalysts with the Cr loading of 7.2% or higher displays a series of strong peaks attributed to α-Cr2O3 and the initial alumina. It should be noted that there was no difference in alumina phase between the fresh and equilibrated catalysts. In addition, for all catalysts, there was no evidence of the formation of solid solution of α-(Cr, Al) which was often reported present in the CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts subject to either very high temperature aging or about one year of operation in the commercial unit [51,52]. Fig. 2 presents the change of amorphous and α-Cr2O3 concentration with the Cr loading. As can be seen, the fresh and equilibrated catalysts had similar α-Cr2O3 concentration which showed continuous increase with the Cr loading. This suggests that the α-Cr2O3 phase formed on the catalyst surface had good stability. In a different way, the amorphous Cr2O3 concentration showed an initial increase up to the maxima of 6.34% and 6.99% in the fresh and equilibrated Cr-Al-9.9 catalysts, respectively, followed by a quick decrease to 3.96% and 4.99%, respectively, in the fresh and equilibrated Cr-Al-13.2 catalysts possibly due to the conversion of amorphous Cr2O3 into α-Cr2O3. To our interest, the equilibrated catalyst always contained 0.5-1.0% higher of amorphous Cr2O3 content than the fresh one. The increase of amorphous Cr2O3 concentration was probably caused by the conversion of Cr6+ species which showed ∼0.51-0.70% decrease for all the equilibrated catalysts. Another interesting finding from the XRD data is that the increase of the Cr loading and aging of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts had no significant effect on the crystallite size of the α-Cr2O3 phase if present. The calculated particle sizes of α-Cr2O3 in the fresh and equilibrated catalysts were very close, in the range of 295–346Å (Table 2, columns 13 and 14). 3.4 Catalyst surface area, chromium oxide surface area and particle size The fresh and equilibrated catalysts were tested to determine the total surface area by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and to calculate the surface area and particle size of chromium oxide clusters by the O2 chemisorption. Fig. 3 A shows the change of the catalyst surface area with the Cr loading. It was expected that the catalyst surface area decreased with the Cr loading. Compared to the fresh catalyst, the equilibrated catalyst showed similarity in the surface area, suggesting that the alumina support was likely stable during the aging. However, the surface area of chromium oxide decreased significantly after the aging test as shown in Fig. 3(b). Among all the catalysts, the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst showed the maximum of ∼90% loss of the surface area of chromium oxide. Increase of the Cr loading seemed to help improve the stability of the chromium oxide particles. For example, the chromium oxide surface in the equilibrated Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst decreased ∼55% as compared to the fresh one, which was significantly less than those for the fresh catalysts with lower Cr loading. The measured chromium oxide surface area was used to calculate the average particle size of chromium oxide. As seen in Table 2, the calculated particle size of chromium oxide increased with the Cr loading. By comparing the average chromium oxide particle size between the fresh and the equilibrated catalyst, it was found that the chromium oxide cluster with an average size of equal or lower than 140Å was not stable on the catalyst surface during the cyclic redox mode of operation. It is worth noting that the fresh and equilibrated Cr-100 had similar chromium oxide surface area of 4.27m2/g and 4.20m2/g, respectively, which shows that the Cr-100 sample was stable during the aging. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis There have been a good amount of published studies on the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst in the literature [17–19] that concluded the presence of Cr3+ and Cr6+ species on the fresh catalyst surface. In this work, the XPS technique was applied to determine the relationship between the atomic ratio of Cr to Al and the total Cr loading in the fresh and equilibrated catalysts. Fig. 4 compares the change of the measured surface Cr/Al ratio with the Cr loading between the fresh and equilibrated catalysts. It is seen that for the fresh catalysts, the Cr/Al ratio showed almost a linear increase from 0.03 to 0.20 as the Cr loading increased from 0.58 to 13.2%. For the equilibrated catalysts, the Cr/Al ratio initially showed an almost parallel increase with that of the fresh catalysts in the Cr loading range of 1.34–7.2%; further increase of the Cr loading slowed down the speed of the Cr/Al ratio growth and reached a plateau in the figure. In addition, the equilibrated catalyst showed a lower Cr/Al ratio compared to the fresh one. For example, the measured Cr/Al ratio decreased from 0.2 to 0.13 down by 35% between the fresh and equilibrated Al-Cr-13.2 catalysts. This observation can be explained by (1) the decreased CrOx surface area in the equilibrated catalyst, and (2) the migration of Cr3+ into the alumina lattice [53]. In addition, this observation also provides additional evidence that restructuring of surface CrOx species occurred during the redox mode of aging. It is possible that thicker or larger CrOx clusters were formed on the equilibrated catalyst surface than those on the fresh one. 3.6 UV-Raman spectroscopy analysis To better understand the structure of Cr species on the catalyst surface, Raman spectra of this series of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts were collected in the wavenumber range of 450–2000cm−1. Fig. 5 (a) compares the Raman spectra of the fresh and equilibrated Al-Cr-0.58 catalysts. As can be seen, two spectra show a similar profile with two strong bands at∼860cm−1 and ∼1730–1780cm−1. The band at 860cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching and bending mode of the chromate species [54–57], and the band at the higher frequency (∼1730–1780cm−1) is considered as the higher order replica of the band at ∼860cm−1. Peak deconvolution of the band at 860cm−1 shows the presence of five peaks as plotted in Fig. 5(b), all of which possibly originate from the Cr6+ species [9,10,55,56]. The peak at 859cm−1 can be assigned to the symmetric stretching and bending modes of ‘isolated’ tetrahedral surface-monochromate (Cr6+) species that is distorted by its interaction with the surface of alumina [10,56]. The term of ‘isolated’ was used here to emphasize that the chromate species do not have interaction with any Cr2O3 cluster, importance of this differentiation will be further understood in the later section. The assignment of this band is also supported by the pH measurement of the CrO3 impregnation solution that was used to prepare the Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst. Due to the low concentration of CrO3, the pH value of the impregnation solution was 7.2. At this pH, an equilibrium between monochromate and dichromates [CrO4 2−]↔[Cr2O7 2−] shifted toward the formation of monochromate in the impregnation solution, which favors the formation of isolated monochromate (Cr6+) species on the alumina surface. The Raman results are also in agreement with those reported by Yim and Nam who observed the strong band at 860cm−1 for the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst with 1% Cr loading [10]. The peak at 941cm−1 appears as a shoulder to the main band at 859cm−1 and can be assigned to the symmetric stretching mode of CrO2 units which terminate the surface species [9]. In a few published papers, this peak was attributed to the formation of hydrated dichromates [10,56,58]. The peaks at 826cm−1 and 896cm−1 are likely attributed to the formation of trichromates or higher degree of chromates. After the aging, the peak at 859cm−1 shifted slightly to 860cm−1, but its intensity was significantly decreased, indicating of the reduction of isolated monochromate(s). This is in very good agreement with the catalyst color change from yellowish to greenish, indicating that a majority of the Cr6+ species in the catalyst were converted into Cr3+ species after the aging. Moreover, it is in line with the measured Cr6+ concentration in the fresh and equilibrated samples showing a drastic reduction of Cr6+ concentration after the aging, where 92% of the initial Cr6+ species were converted into Cr3+ species (Table 2, columns 1 and 2). Fig. 5(c) shows the Raman spectrum of the fresh Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst in the wavenumber range of 600–1100cm−1. As can be seen, the original band at 859cm−1 in the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst shifted to a higher frequency position at 861cm−1 in the fresh Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst. In addition, the peak intensity in the fresh Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst decreased as compared to that in the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst. This suggests that the increase of the Cr loading resulted in the reduction of isolated monochromate species, possibly leading to the formation of higher degree of chromates species [54]. Deconvolution of the peak at 861cm−1 revealed the presence of a shoulder peak at 894cm−1, the intensity of which was much higher than its corresponding peak in the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst. This observation indicates that the increase of Cr loading led to a higher portion of the polymeric chromate species on its surface, which was also supported by the low pH (<<4) impregnation solution used for the preparation of the Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst. The lower pH condition was more favorable for the formation of dichromates in the impregnation solution than monochromates [59], creating a condition for the formation of dichromates, trichromates, and even polychromates on the catalyst surface. Compared to the fresh Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst, the equilibrated one shows similar Raman spectrum as shown in Fig. 5(d). Deconvolution of the wide band in the range of 600–1100cm−1 shows the presence of five peaks. Compared to the fresh sample, all five peaks in the equilibrated sample shifted to the positions at lower frequencies. Another significant difference in the spectra between the fresh and equilibrated Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst is that the peaks (861cm−1 for the fresh sample, 854cm−1 for the equilibrated sample) representing the isolated monochromates decreased, while the peaks (828cm−1 for the fresh sample, 822cm−1 for the equilibrated sample) representing the higher polymerization degree of chromates increased. This shows that the formation of higher polymerization degree of chromates was more favorable than the monochromates during the aging. To our surprise, in spite of the increase of the total Cr6+ concentration, further increase of the Cr loading to 9.9%, the intensity of the wide band in the range of 600–110cm−1 dropped significantly as shown in Fig. 5(e). Deconvolution of the wide band shows only four peaks for the fresh Al-Cr-9.9 catalyst. The original shoulder peak at 931cm−1 in the fresh Al-Cr-4.6 disappeared and all other peak intensities decreased. After the aging, there was only one peak centered at 783cm-1 left as shown in Fig. 5(f), and all other three peaks of 824, 860, and 886cm−1 in Fig. 5(e) attributed to different degree of chromates were all disappeared. Further increase of the Cr loading to 13.2%, the Raman spectra (not shown for brevity) of the fresh and equilibrated Al-Cr-13.2 catalysts show only one weak peak centered at ∼788cm−1 in the wavenumber range of 600–1100cm−1, which look similar to the spectrum of the equilibrated Al-Cr-9.9 catalyst. It should be noted that the deconvoluted broad peak at ∼770–786cm−1 was possibly associated with the background in all samples. Although α-Cr2O3 was detected in the CrOx/alumina catalyst with the Cr loading of 4.6% or higher, none of the Raman spectra shows the presence of peak at 550cm−1 attributed to Cr2O3. Similar results were reported by Vuurman and Wachs who applied the Raman spectroscopy to study two CrOx/alumina catalysts prepared by different Cr precursors, i.e., chromium nitrate and chromic acid, and found that the peak at 550cm−1 was shown in the spectrum of the catalyst made by chromium nitrate, not by chromic acid [54]. 3.7 TPR analysis Fig. 6 (a) compares the TPR results between the fresh and equilibrated Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst. The fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst shows one strong reduction peak centered at 329°C. According to its Raman spectrum, the reduction peak should be attributed to the reduction of isolated aluminum monochromate and polychromate. There was no reduction peak observed for the equilibrated catalyst, which suggests that all the Cr6+ species present in the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 sample were not stable under the aging conditions. Fig. 6(b) compares the TPR results between the fresh and equilibrated Al-Cr-9.9 catalysts. Similar to the fresh Al-Cr-0.58, the TPR of the fresh Al-Cr-9.9 catalyst shows one strong reduction peak centered at 328°C. After the aging, the peak shifted to a higher temperatures of 340°C with reduced peak intensity, which is in agreement with the decrease of measured Cr6+ concentration in the two samples (0.97% vs. 0.46%). It should be noted that the position of the reduction peaks in the TPR shifted from ∼320–329°C observed for the fresh samples to ∼340–346°C for the equilibrated ones (Fig. 6b). This observation indicates that the initial redox Cr6+ species formed during the preparation of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst disappeared from the catalyst surface after the aging, accompanying the formation of new types of redox Cr6+ species which require a higher reduction temperature. 4 Discussion 4.1 Identification and stability evaluation of surface Cr species 4.1.1 Nature of surface Cr6+ species and their stability Given the alumina support was stable during the aging, all changes observed between the fresh and the equilibrated catalysts were considered to be related with the change of surface Cr species. In spite of the low Cr loading, the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst containing only Cr6+ species had 5.6m2/g of chromium oxide surface area, which was only ∼3 times lower than that of the fresh Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst which had 22.7 times higher Cr loading. This suggests that the size of surface Cr species for the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 was much smaller than that for the fresh Al-Cr-13.2. The Raman spectra of this catalyst also showed that the ‘isolated’ aluminum-monochromate, dichromate, and polychromate were likely formed on the catalyst surface, of which the aluminum monochromate was probably the dominant species. The ‘isolated’ aluminum mono-/poly-chromates have been reported previously, and their structure was illustrated in Table 3 [60,61]. After the aging, a series of drastic changes of the catalyst properties was observed: (1) the measured chromium oxide surface area decreased from 5.6m2/g to 0.8m2/g, (2) ∼91.4% of the initial Cr6+ species was converted into amorphous Cr2O3, (3) the catalyst color changed from yellowish to greenish, (4) the Raman peak that represents the isolated monochromate showed a drastic reduction of its intensity, (5) the surface Cr/Al atomic ratio decreased from 0.03 to 0.02; and (6) the strong reduction peak of the isolated Cr6+ species seen in the TPR of the fresh catalyst completely disappeared showing that the equilibrated catalyst had no reducible Cr6+ species. All these observations suggest that the surface Cr6+ species, in the form of ‘isolated’ aluminum mono-/poly-chromate, were not stable. After the aging, most of Cr6+ species were converted into amorphous Cr2O3. Unlike the fresh Al-Cr-0.58, the fresh Al-Cr-1.3 contained ∼56.3% Cr6+ and ∼43.7% Cr3+ species. Aging of this catalyst led to the conversion of approximately 85% of its initial Cr6+ species into Cr3+ species. Further increase of the Cr loading to 4.6% caused a small increase of the total Cr6+ species concentration from 0.77% to 0.91% but a significant increase of the Cr3+ species portion in the fresh catalyst from 42.5% to 80%. It should be mentioned that most of the Cr3+ species were attributed to the formation of amorphous Cr2O3. The Raman spectra of the fresh Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst indicated that a majority of the surface Cr6+ species were likely ‘isolated’ polychromate species. Aging of the Al-Cr-4.6 caused a drastic reduction of Cr6+, ∼80% of the initial Cr6+ species being converted into the Cr3+ species which comprised 94% amorphous Cr2O3 and 6% α-Cr2O3. For the catalysts with the Cr loading of 7.2% or higher, the aging also caused the Cr6+ concentration to decrease. However, the extent of the initial Cr6+ loss was much lower than those for the catalyst with the Cr loading of 4.6% or lower. Fig. 7 shows the changes of the remaining Cr6+ portion and the total Cr3+ concentration in the equilibrated catalysts as a function of the total Cr loading. The total Cr3+ concentration was calculated as the sum of amorphous Cr2O3 and crystalline α-Cr2O3 concentration. As can be seen, the portion of remaining Cr6+ species increased from 8.6% to 51.4% as the total Cr loading increased from 0.58% to 13.2%, suggesting that a higher Cr loading favored the formation of more stable redox Cr6+ species which were rejuvenated on their own after the aging. To our interest, the total Cr6+concentration in the equilibrated catalysts showed almost a linear increase with the total Cr loading, which correlates very well with the increase of the Cr3+ portion left on the catalyst in Fig. 7. The correlation suggests that the formation of Cr3+ species may help stabilize or regenerate the redox Cr6+ species during the high temperature of re-oxidation. The Cr3+ species have been reported to act as a reservoir of Cr6+ oxide in the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst by Cavani et al. who found that the part of Cr6+ species washed out by water reappeared in the catalyst after the re-calcination, accompanying the reduction of the surface Cr3+ portion [20]. To better understand the role of Cr3+ species, including amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3, in the formation of re-dox Cr6+, it is very necessary to reinvestigate the Cr2O3 re-oxidation. The Cr2O3 compound is considered very stable, and its re-oxidation has been studied before [61–65]. However, there has been no consistent conclusion made in the literature. For example, Karapetyanz and Karapetyanz [61] and Rode [62] reported that Cr2O3 is the most stable chromium compound among all chromium oxides, and the oxidation of Cr2O3 by oxygen is thermodynamically improbable at temperatures higher than 300°C; while Davydov and co-workers [63,64] and Carrott and Sheppard [65] observed the re-oxidation of pure Cr2O3 by oxygen using IR spectroscopy. McDaniel and Burwell [66] elucidated the details of the introduction of excess oxygen into Cr2O3 during its drying or as a result of the adsorption of oxygen on activated chromia. They confirmed the existence of chromium chromate Cr6+ and measured its amount on Cr2O3 as a function of preparation variables. Also, they found that the chromium chromate served as a flux to catalyst the conversion of amorphous Cr2O3 to α-Cr2O3. To verify whether pure Cr2O3 can be re-oxidized during the redox operation, a high purity (>99%) of Cr2O3 sample was made by the decomposition of CrO3 at 600°C. The sample was thermally treated in two steps: the first step was to reduce the sample in H2 at 600°C for 4h, and the second step was to re-oxidize the reduced sample in air at 600°C for 4h. Two samples were obtained after each treatment and analyzed by XPS and chemical analysis. The chemical analysis shows that the Cr6+ concentration decreased from the initial 0.1% to 0.01% after the reduction, but regained 0.1% after the re-oxidation. The XPS results for the two samples are given in Fig. 8 . It is seen that both XPS spectra show the presence of Cr3+ and Cr6+ species. Compared to the reduced sample, the sample after reduction and re-oxidation showed increased intensity of peaks at 589eV and 579eV which were assigned to CrO3 [17,19]. These observations confirmed that Cr2O3 can be oxidized in air at 600°C to form the Cr6+ species, but its conversion degree was very low yielding ∼0.2% of CrO3. To further study the type of Cr6+ species, the TPR measurement was performed on the Cr2O3 powder, and the result is given in Fig. 9 (a). As can be seen, there are two weak reduction peaks centered at 247°C and 522°C, respectively, suggesting the formation of two types of Cr6+ ions. For direct comparison, Fig. 9(b) compares the TPR spectra between the Cr2O3 powder and the fresh Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst. The Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst was selected due to it contained the highest amount of Cr2O3, ∼19.2%, among the series of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts. As can be seen, the TPR of the fresh Al-Cr-13.2 shows a strong peak and two weak peaks (magnified by 5 times). Both spectra show one weak reduction peak centered at ∼522°C, indicating the presence of an additional type of Cr6+ species in the sample with very low concentration. This observation is consistent with the report by Zaki and co-workers who presumed that the new Cr6+ species were stabilized by bonding with Cr2O3 in the form of the chromium-chromate after the re-oxidation [67,68]. The structure of the chromium-chromate was given in Table 3. Thus, it is inferred that the chromium-chromate can be formed on the surface of the Cr2O3 clusters but their concentration was negligible according to the TPR data. Moreover, the TPR of the equilibrated catalyst clearly indicated that the main reduction peak is centered at 340–349°C, which was not present in the TPR of Cr2O3 (Fig. 9a). Thus, the presence of chromium-chromate failed to explain that there was ∼0.55% Cr6+ species on the equilibrated Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst surface. This suggests that there must be other type(s) of Cr6+ species which are not only stable, but also account for the majority of the redox Cr6+ species in the equilibrated catalysts. It is plausible that one type of Cr6+ species was likely generated from the conversion of Cr2O3, according to the strong correlation between the Cr6+ portion and the Cr3+ concentration present on the equilibrated catalyst surface as shown in Fig. 7. As discussed above, the re-oxidation of Cr2O3 to CrO3 was difficult even at 600°C in air. However, the addition of such metal oxides as TiO2 and Al2O3 to Cr2O3 has been reported to promote the re-oxidation of Cr2O3 to form CrO3 with an optimal temperature of∼600°C [69–71]. To prove this concept, a mixture was made by physically mixing alumina and α-Cr2O3 powder. The α-Cr2O3 powder was prepared by the calcination of CrO3 flakes at 760°C in air for 4h and contained ∼0.1% of Cr6+ showing dark green color. The mixture showed light greenish with measured 0.02% Cr6+ and 20% α-Cr2O3 (corresponding to the 13% Cr loading). Fig. 10 compares the Raman spectra of the mixture before and after the calcination at 600°C in air in the wavenumber range of 600–1100cm−1. The spectrum of the un-calcined mixture showed a broad and weak peak in the range of 700–1000cm−1. The mixture was then divided into two parts. The first part was calcined at 600°C for 2h under air flow, which resulted in the change of sample color from green to yellowish. The resulting sample had 1.05% of Cr6+ species and 4.5% of α-Cr2O3. This suggests that (1) the addition of alumina to α-Cr2O3 can indeed facilitate the conversion of Cr2O3 to form more Cr6+ species (∼7.9% % vs. 0.1% on the basis of Cr2O3) as compared to Cr2O3 alone, and (2) ∼78% of initial α-Cr2O3 was converted into amorphous Cr2O3. The Raman spectrum of the calcined mixture shows a strong peak centered at 870cm−1 indicating the formation of other type(s) of chromate (Cr6+). The second part was calcined at 600°C for 2h under N2 flow, during which there was no color change. The resulting mixture was found to contain only 0.03% Cr6+. Therefore, air also played an important role in the formation of Cr6+ species from the Cr2O3 conversion. Our tests clearly showed that up to 8% of Cr3+ species in Cr2O3 can be converted into Cr6+ species in the presence of alumina and air under the dehydrogenation temperatures (550°C–650°C) by gas-solid phase reactions. The first question then arose as to whether the Cr6+ species, formed from the Cr2O3 oxidation, were present as ‘isolated’ aluminum chromate(s). From the point we stand, it is unlikely to form ‘isolated’ aluminum-chromate(s) through the conversion of Cr3+ oxide, since it requires the breakage of many bonds to be away from Cr2O3 clusters. In addition, as discussed in Section 3.7, the TPR results suggest the formation of new type(s) of Cr6+ species on the equilibrated catalyst surface which require a higher reduction temperature than the initial isolated Cr6+ species in the fresh catalyst. Given Cr has ability to form mixed valence of CrOx compounds [72], it is hypothesized that the new Cr6+ sites converted from Cr2O3 continued to be a part of the Cr2O3 cluster and were coupled with both the Cr2O3 cluster and alumina. Previous studies have provided evidence of the bonding between the Cr6+ and Cr3+ species. For example, Weller and Voltz [73] observed the simultaneous presence of Cr3+ and Cr6+ species in Cr2O3 after the reduction and re-oxidation. A very similar conclusion was also made by Fahim et al. who observed the Cr6+-Cr3+ coupled pair-sites in α-Cr2O3 particles being a part of CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst [67]. In another paper, Zaki et al. had a bold hypothesis that the pairs of Cr6+-Cr3+ sites may have a structure of chromium-chromate(s) [68]. The new type of Cr6+ species was designated as the ‘aluminum-chromium-chromate(s)’, and its representative structure was proposed in Table 3. It is predictable that coupling of the Cr6+ species with alumina and Cr2O3 made the new species to be more stable than the ‘isolated’ aluminum-chromate species. Another question was what kind of Cr3+ atoms in the Cr2O3 clusters interacted with alumina to form the aluminum-chromium-chromate (Cr6+) species during the calcination. Based on the above discussion, it was believed that the right type of Cr3+ atoms should meet at least two requirements: (1) they should have direct contact with Al atoms, and (2) they should be exposed to air. Careful analysis of all possible Cr3+species present on the CrOx/alumina catalyst surface suggests that there is only one type of Cr3+ atom from the Cr2O3 cluster which satisfies both requirements. The right type of Cr atoms should be located on the border of the Cr2O3 clusters in between Cr2O3 and alumina surface. The stability of the aluminum-chromium-chromate(s) species depends on the stability of the Cr2O3 cluster. If the Cr2O3 cluster has strong bonding with alumina and does not migrate on the catalyst surface during the redox operation, the Cr6+ species would reappear after the catalyst regeneration. However, if the Cr6+ species are weakly bonded with small Cr2O3 clusters which can easily migrate and colloid with each other to form new and large ones on the catalyst surface during the dehydrogenation and steam purge steps, the properties of Cr6+ species are very likely to change. The formation of the larger Cr2O3 clusters causes the reduction of the total amount of clusters and the Cr3+ atoms located at the border of the clusters. As a result, the amount of redox aluminum-chromium-chromate(s) decreased during the regeneration step. Fig. 11 schematically shows the reduction of the Cr6+ species concentration caused by the agglomeration of the Cr2O3 clusters and by the reduction of interphase between chromia and alumina on the catalyst surface during a full cycle. It should be noted that not all aluminum atoms are capable of promoting the re-oxidation of Cr3+ to Cr6+ as suggested by the fact of (1) the Cr6+ concentration in the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst was always limited within 2–3%, and (2) further increase of the total Cr loading would not further increase of Cr6+ species [20]. Lewis acid site, which can pick up the electron pair from Cr3+ and mediate its conversion to Cr6+, is possibly one type of active site for the re-oxidation of Cr3+ species on the alumina surfaces. However, the amount of Lewis acid sites on the alumina surface is limited. 4.1.2 Nature and stability of surface Cr3+ species The fresh Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst had only ‘isolated’ aluminum-chromate(s) Cr6+ species and there was no Cr2O3 cluster formed on the catalyst surface, while ∼42.5% of the total Cr in the fresh Al-Cr-1.34 catalyst was in the form of amorphous Cr2O3. Further increase of the Cr loading resulted in the simultaneous increase of the Cr3+ and Cr6+ amounts and the ratio of Cr3+/Cr6+. Moreover, increasing the Cr loading in the fresh catalyst resulted in the increase of the average particle size of Cr2O3 from 16Å in the Al-Cr-0.58 catalyst to 140Å in the Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst. Aging the catalyst resulted in a drastic increase of the average particle size of Cr2O3. For example, the particle size of Cr2O3 increased from 16Å for the fresh Al-Cr-0.58 to 110Å for the equilibrated Al-Cr-0.58. The fresh Al-Cr-4.6 catalyst had 12.5m2/g of chromium oxide surface area and an average chromium oxide particle size of 64Å. Aging the catalyst resulted in drastic decrease of the chromium oxide surface area by 3 times and increase of the chromium oxide particle size. Thus, the Cr2O3 particles with a size of ∼64Å or smaller were not stable on the alumina surface during the redox aging. At least four types of Cr species were likely present in the Al-Cr-7.2, Al-Cr-9.9 and Al-Cr-13.2 catalysts, i.e., the aluminum-chromate(s) Cr6+, the chromium-chromate(s) Cr6+, the amorphous Cr2O3, and the α-Cr2O3 phase. The average chromium oxide particle size in the three fresh catalyst was 87Å, 110Å, and 140Å, respectively, and increased to 245Å, 290Å and 340Å, respectively, in the equilibrated catalysts. This observation suggests that the Cr2O3 clusters with ∼300Å particle size can be considered as relatively stable. The Cr2O3 clusters of lower than 300Å should be considered unstable. It is reasonable that the stability of the Cr2O3 clusters on the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst surface depends on their adsorption behavior onto alumina. These clusters can be either physically or chemically adsorbed onto the alumina surface through the Cr3+-O-Al3+ bonds. There are a few studies in the literature that compared different chromium species formed on the surfaces of alumina and silica [56,74]. The authors concluded that the interaction between Cr3+ and alumina is stronger than that between Cr3+ and silica, which was attributed to the presence of chemical bonding between Cr3+ and alumina. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no literature which provides the strength of the Cr3+-O-Al3+ bonds, but there is information regarding the length of the Cr3+-O and Cr6+-O bonds, which are 0.2nm and 0.167nm, respectively [75]. In this work, the chemical bond length was used to compare the strength between the Cr3+-O-Al3+ and the Cr6+-O-Al3+ bonds. Due to the longer Cr3+-O bond length, the strength of the Cr3+-O-Al3+ bonds is most likely weaker as compared to that of the Cr6+-O-Al3+ bonds, which favors high mobility of small Cr2O3 clusters on the alumina surface during the redox operation. Smaller Cr2O3 clusters tended to migrate on the catalyst surface to form larger clusters (the average cluster size >300Å), which was driven by the increase of the amount of interfacial Cr3+-O-Al3+ bonds to help stabilize the Cr2O3 clusters on the catalyst surface. Increasing the Cr loading from 4.6% to 7.2% resulted in double increase of Cr2O3 concentration in the fresh catalyst, most of which were amorphous Cr2O3. Further increase of the Cr loading to 9.9% caused simultaneous increase of α-Cr2O3 and amorphous Cr2O3 in the catalyst. However, the amorphous Cr2O3 concentration started to decrease as the Cr loading increased to 13.2%. This implicates the increase of α-Cr2O3 concentration was likely caused by the conversion of a portion of amorphous Cr2O3 during the catalyst preparation. Aging the fresh catalyst which contained α-Cr2O3 showed slight change of the α-Cr2O3 concentration and the crystallite size as shown in Fig. 2. This observation serves as an evidence that α-Cr2O3 was relatively stable on the alumina surface during the redox aging, which could explain the results of the Cr-100 sample showing almost no change of the catalyst surface area and chromium oxide surface area before and after the aging as shown in Table 2. To our interest, the migration and agglomeration of amorphous Cr2O3 clusters during the aging would not increase the α-Cr2O3 concentration in the equilibrated catalyst. 4.2 The CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst model for paraffin dehydrogenation A new catalyst model for the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst was proposed in this paper. The model applies to the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst with a high Cr loading of 13% or higher for the paraffin dehydrogenation use. Since the preparation of the high Cr loading CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst is usually carried out by the impregnation of alumina with high concentration of chromic acid aqueous solution, the impregnation solution typically has a pH<1. The Cr species in the impregnation solution are predominantly in the form of dimer (Cr2O7 2−), trimer (Cr3O10 2−), or even tetramer (Cr4O13 2−), which favor the formation of polychromates on the alumina surface after the impregnation. As discussed above, there are likely at least five types of Cr species formed on the fresh Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst surface which were summarized in Table 4 . Three types of redox Cr6+ species were identified including the ‘isolated’ poly aluminum-chromate, the chromium-chromate species formed on the surface of Cr2O3, and the aluminum-chromium-chromate coupled with Cr2O3 cluster. Since the portion of the redox Cr6+ species in the Al-Cr-13.2 catalyst was only ∼8.1% relative to the Cr loading, it is very likely that most of amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 clusters were not coupled with the redox Cr6+ species. Both amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3, no matter whether they are coupled with the aluminum-chromium-chromate or not, constitute as the source of the non-redox Cr3+ species. In addition, the probability of forming ‘isolated’ monochromate(s) and redox Cr3+ species should be low for the high Cr loading CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst due to the absence of the monochromate ions, [CrO4]2−, in the impregnation solution. Fig. 12 schematically shows the conversion of ‘isolated’ mono/poly aluminum chromate (Cr6+) in the fresh catalyst into the aluminum-chromium-chromate (Cr6+) species coupled with Cr2O3 clusters during a full redox cycle. It should be noted that the situation in Fig. 12 is only valid under a certain Cr loading in which there is a sufficient amount of alumina surface area and hydroxyl groups available to anchor the higher oxidation states of Cr. For the fresh catalyst, most of the surface Cr species were relatively stable under oxidative atmosphere. During the reduction step which precedes the dehydrogenation-regeneration cycle, the change of the oxidation state of these species was most likely accompanied by the breakage and/or weakening of the chemical bonds between these species with alumina support. The reduction of mono/poly aluminum-chromates (Cr6+) by H2 resulted in the formation of Cr2O3, mostly in the form of small Cr2O3 clusters. The steam formed by the reaction (2) might help to mobilize the Cr2O3 clusters on the alumina surface. (2) CrO3+ H2 →Cr2O3 +H2O During the reduction, dehydrogenation and steam purge stages, it is likely that small Cr2O3 clusters migrate and colloid with each other to form large Cr2O3 clusters. The mobility of small Cr2O3 clusters may be enhanced by the presence of large amount of steam during the steam purge. During the regeneration step, the newly formed large Cr2O3 clusters are more likely further developed into the redox chromium-chromate(s) and the aluminum-chromium-chromate(s) coupled with Cr2O3 through the oxidation of the Cr3+ atoms located on the border of the Cr2O3 clusters. Amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 are the main Cr species present on both the fresh and equilibrated CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst surfaces. Despite that the amorphous Cr2O3 clusters have weaker bonding with alumina via the Cr3+-O-Al3+ bonds than the ‘isolated’ aluminum chromate via the Cr6+-O-Al3+, they can show relatively stable and low mobility on the catalyst surface if their sizes are large enough to provide sufficient amount of interfacial Cr3+-O-Al3+ bonds. For example, it was found that the Cr2O3 cluster can maintain its initial size and location during the aging when its size is ∼300Å or higher. After the re-oxidation, they can regain their initial amounts of the redox Cr6+ species coupled with Cr2O3, thus maintaining high stability under reductive and oxidative atmosphere. The crystalline α-Cr2O3 clusters are considered as the most stable among all the Cr species. Table 4 summarizes the stability evaluation of Cr species present in the fresh and equilibrated catalysts. 5 Conclusions In this study we have in detail studied a series of fresh and equilibrated CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with the Cr loading in the range of 0.58–13.2% using combined techniques, including XPS, XRD, O2 chemisorption, TPR, STEM/EDX, Raman, and chemical analysis etc., to identify the surface Cr species and to evaluate their stability. The following useful conclusions have been drawn: 1. At least five types of Cr species were present on the fresh catalyst surface, including: 1) ‘Isolated’ mono-/poly- aluminum chromate(s); 2) Redox chromium-chromate(s) on the surface of amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 clusters; 3) Redox aluminum-chromium-chromate(s) on the border of the coupled amorphous or crystalline Cr2O3 clusters; 4) Non-redox Cr3+ species on the surface of amorphous Cr2O3 clusters with different size; 5) Non-redox Cr3+ species on the surface of crystalline Cr2O3 clusters with different size. 2. Initial operation of the fresh CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst at the dehydrogenation-regeneration mode caused the complete surface restructuring of unstable chromium species, resulting in the formation of the equilibrated one. The stability evaluation of different Cr species on the CrOx/alumina catalyst surfaces was performed, and the following conclusions can be drawn: 1) The ‘isolated’ aluminum-chromate species were not stable and disappeared after the break-in period operation and not present on the surface of equilibrated catalyst; 2) Weakly bonded amorphous Cr2O3 clusters with the average size of less than 300Å were not stable on the surface of alumina. They tended to migrate and collide with each other to form large size and relatively stable Cr2O3 clusters. The equilibrated catalyst contains the Cr2O3 clusters with an average size of ∼300Å or larger; 3) The cyclic redox operation of the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst decreases the amount of redox Cr6+ species by eliminating the ‘isolated’ aluminum chromate, leaving aluminum chromium chromate Cr6+ sites coupled with amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 clusters on the surface; 4) Crystalline α-Cr2O3 clusters can be considered as the most stable species. coredata.dc:description: In this study a series of the fresh and equilibrated CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with the Cr loading from 0.58wt% to 13.2wt% were in detail studied using combined techniques, including Raman spectroscopy, TEM, XPS, O2 chemisorption, TPR, XRD and chemical analysis, to identify surface chromium species and to evaluate their stability under the cyclic dehydrogenation-regeneration (redox) conditions. The study showed that the stable chromium species present in the equilibrated CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst can be achieved through complete surface restructuring of initial chromium species in the fresh one under the redox conditions. This study also showed that the fresh CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst contained not only previously known chromium species of ‘isolated’ mono/poly aluminum chromate(s), amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3 clusters with different sizes, but also chromium-chromate (Cr6+) species on the surface of Cr2O3 clusters and aluminum-chromium-chromate (Cr6+) species coupled with Cr2O3 clusters. The ‘isolated’ aluminum chromate(s) and small Cr2O3 clusters on the catalyst surface were not stable under the cyclic redox conditions and disappeared after the break-in-period of the catalyst operation. The paper presents the mechanism of the surface restructuring of chromium species under the redox conditions and the revised model for the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst with the consideration of the change of surface chromium species caused by the cyclic redox aging. The model can be applied to the commercial CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Investigating the CrOx/Al2O3 dehydrogenation catalyst model: I. identification and stability evaluation of the Cr species on the fresh and equilibrated catalysts
